graphic.content: # OF

Click keys or type to add symbols
to the score above.

Click tabs to the left or press spacebar to
switch between keyboards.

Mouse over the keyboard for help.
Augmentation Dot
Place dot(s) after the affected note.
Note Symbols

Each symbol specifies both pitch and length. An octave symbol must
be placed before the note, except after:
 a leap of a fourth or fifth within the same octave, or
 a leap of a third or less (even if the octave changes).
Octave Symbols
Octave symbols are placed before the note affected.
Octave Symbols
Octave symbols are placed before the note affected.
Octave Symbols
Octave symbols are placed before the note affected.
Octave Symbols
Octave symbols are placed before the note affected.
Octave Symbols
Octave symbols are placed before the note affected.
Octave Symbols
Octave symbols are placed before the note affected.
Octave Symbols
Octave symbols are placed before the note affected.
Octave Symbols
Octave symbols are placed before the note affected.
Octave Symbols
Octave symbols are placed before the note affected.
Rest Symbols
As in traditional notation, the whole rest symbol can be used\nas a measure rest in any meter.
Place the accidental before the affected note.
Interval Symbols

Place intervals after notes to create chords. For melodies, intervals are\nread downward; for bass lines, intervals are read upward. Accidentals or\noctave marks may be placed before the affected interval.
Tie Symbol
Place the tie symbol between notes to be connected.
Time Signatures

Time signatures consist of three characters: the meter prefix, the top number,
and the bottom number. The initial time signature and key signature should be
centered horizontally above the first line of music. Meter changes should be
separated from surrounding music with blank spaces.
Time Signature Abbreviations

The common time and cut time abbreviations do not require the meter prefix.
The initial time signature and key signature should be centered horizontally above
the first line of music. Meter changes should be separated from surrounding
music with blank spaces.
Key Signatures

For keys of three accidentals or fewer, simply use the appropriate number
of accidentals. Otherwise, use the key prefix, a multiplier, and a single
accidental. The initial time signature and key signature should be centered
horizontally above the first line of music.
Tuplet indicators are placed before the first note in the group.\nFor simple triplets, the single triplet symbol may be used.
Tuplet indicators are placed before the first note in the group.\nFor simple triplets, the single triplet symbol may be used.
Short Slur
To slur two notes together, place the short slur symbol\nbetween them.
Long Slur
To slur more than two notes together, place the begin slur symbol\nbefore the first note and the end slur symbol after the last note.
Articulations & Special Noteheads
Place articulations before the note affected. Use doubled symbols to\nuse an articulation until specified otherwise.
Music Prefix
Use the music prefix symbol before music symbols\non lines which mix music and text.
Text Prefix
Use the text prefix symbol before literary braille\non lines which mix music and text.
Place dynamics before the first note affected.
Gradual Dynamic Changes
To indicate a gradual dynamic change, place the Begin symbol before\nthe first note affected and the End symbol after the last note affected.
Generally, measures are delineated in braille music with a space; the\nSingle Barline symbol is used only when necessary for clarity.
Marking Repeated Sections

Mark sections to repeat by placing the segno symbol followed
by a letter before the section, and the End Repeat symbol afterward.
These symbols only mark the section; use D.S. to indicate
when the section is to be repeated.
Measure Repeat
This repeat symbol can be used to indicate a repeat of the last full\nmeasure or partial measure.
Playing Marked Sections
To instruct performer to play a previously marked section, use D.S.\nfollowed by the section letter, then Number of Measures\nfollowed by the measure length of the section.
Literary Braille
To include text, use literary braille. If music and text is mixed on a single\nline, use the Text Prefix and Music Prefix to switch between systems.
Clefs are unnecessary in braille music, which requires octave\nsymbols to indicate register, but are sometimes included to\ncorrelate with printed scores.
Braille Music Comma
The braille music comma is generally used to show divisions\nthat are normally shown in traditional notation with\nbeamed note groups.
Value Signs

Because 16th, 32nd, 64th and 128th notes use the same
braille symbols as whole, half, quarter and eighth notes,
respectively, these symbols are sometimes placed before
note groupings for clarification when the values cannot be
discerned from context.
Metronome Marking Equals Sign
This symbol is used in metronome markings.
Multimeasure Rests
For three or fewer measures' rest, use consecutive whole rests.\nFor rests lasting four measures or longer, surround a number\nwith beginning and ending rest signs.
Braille Music Hyphen
The braille music hyphen indicates allows for a single measure\nto be broken into multiple lines.
Fingering symbols appear immediately after the notes they affect.
Right/Left Hand
These symbols appear at the beginning of each line for multi-hand\ninstruments (like piano) to indicate which hand should play the line.
Grace Note
This symbol appears before the note to indicate a grace note.
This symbol is placed between two simultaneous voices in a single\nmeasure. An octave designation must occur after the symbol and\nat the beginning of the following measure.
Partial Measure In-Accord
These symbols indicate when only a portion of a\nmeasure has more than one simultaneous voice.
Chord Symbols
These symbols are used with literary braille to\nindicate chords for analysis or lead sheets.
Repeat Symbols
These symbols are used in braille just as in\ntraditional music notation.
